subject: Real Estate
title: The Manhattan Purchase Myth
description: Learn The Manhattan Purchase Myth in one minute.

hook.text: In 1626, the Dutch 'bought' Manhattan from the Lenape for $24 worth of goods. Or so the legend goes.

buildup.text: The only record is a letter mentioning 60 guilders. The $24 figure was calculated in the 1840s.

discovery.text: The Lenape likely didn't believe land could be owned. They may have seen it as a sharing agreement.

twist.text: If that $24 had been invested at 6% compound interest, it would now exceed Manhattan's total property value.

climax.text: The Manhattan purchase is less about a bargain and more about two cultures with incompatible ideas of ownership.

punchline.text: They didn't sell Manhattan. They didn't think you could.

quiz.question: Why might the Lenape not have considered the Manhattan deal a 'sale'?
options: They didn't believe land could be owned
They were forced by the military
